title: Chord: Dominant 7th in G# (Shape: C)
content:
### Description:
The Dominant 7th chord in G# (notated as G#7) is built by taking the 1st (G#), 3rd (B#), 5th (D#), and b7th (F#) degrees of the G# major scale. While the chord is notated as a G#7, it is shaped like a C chord on the guitar. This chord shape produces a strong tension in the harmony, making it a popular choice for creating movement and tension in a piece of music.

### Notes:
- Root (G#)
- Major 3rd (B#)
- Perfect 5th (D#)
- Minor 7th (F#)

### Intervals:
- Root to Major 3rd: Major 3rd
- Root to Perfect 5th: Perfect 5th
- Root to Minor 7th: Minor 7th
- Major 3rd to Perfect 5th: Minor 2nd (or augmented unison)
- Major 3rd to Minor 7th: Perfect 5th
- Perfect 5th to Minor 7th: Minor 3rd

### Genre and Flavor:
The Dominant 7th chord in G# is commonly found in various genres such as jazz, blues, funk, and R&B. This chord provides a sense of tension and is often used to lead smoothly back to the tonic chord, creating a sense of resolution. Its sound is characterized by a mix of richness and dissonance which adds color and flavor to a musical piece.

### Popular Songs:
1. "Sweet Home Chicago" by Robert Johnson
2. "All Blues" by Miles Davis
3. "I Got Rhythm" by George Gershwin
